title: 105_hr4850
content: The Act titled "Rocky Mountain National Park Wilderness Act of 1998" aims to designate certain lands within Rocky Mountain National Park as part of the National Wilderness Preservation System to protect their scenic, historic, and wildlife values, as well as scientific, educational, and recreational resources. Designation of approximately 249,562 acres of lands within Rocky Mountain National Park, Colorado as wilderness under the Rocky Mountain National Park Wilderness Act of 1998. The Secretary of the Interior is required to file a map and boundary description of the designated wilderness lands with the relevant committees of the House of Representatives and the Senate. The Secretary of the Interior is required to file a map and boundary description of designated wilderness lands with the relevant committees of the House of Representatives and the Senate. The map and description will be on file for public inspection in the office of the Director of the National Park Service. SEC. 3. ADMINISTRATIVE PROVISIONS. The lands designated as wilderness by this Act will be managed by the Secretary of the Interior in accordance with the Wilderness Act. Any reference in the Wilderness Act to its effective date will be considered the date of enactment of this Act. Lands identified as "potential wilderness" on the map will also be included. The Act designates potential wilderness lands in Rocky Mountain National Park to be managed as part of the National Wilderness Preservation System. The Congress acknowledges existing water rights within the park, eliminating the need for additional water rights reservation. The Act acknowledges existing water rights in Rocky Mountain National Park and states that no additional water rights reservation is needed for the wilderness designations made. Activities related to the Colorado-Big Thompson Project on designated wilderness lands are allowed to continue without being affected by the wilderness designation. The Act allows for activities related to the Colorado-Big Thompson Project on designated wilderness lands to continue in response to emergencies, with restrictions to protect wilderness values. No development of reclamation projects is permitted within the designated wilderness areas. No development of reclamation projects is permitted within the designated wilderness areas. Exclusions from the wilderness and potential wilderness areas designated by this Act include the Grand Ditch, lands owned by the St. Vrain & Left Hand Water Conservancy District, and any lands not included within the designated boundaries. Congress does not intend for the designation of wilderness areas in Colorado to create buffer zones. Nonwilderness activities or uses visible or audible from within a wilderness area are not prohibited up to the boundary of the wilderness area.
